headline.main: LOSS OF THE ARCTIC.; NARRATIVES OF THE SURVIVORS. INTENSE SUFFERINGS AT SEA. Capt. Lnee of the Arctic, Mrs. E. K. Collins, Due de Grammont, and others, Lost. Arrival f Eighteen Survivors at this Portt HIGHLY NTERESTING PARTICULARS.. RESCUE OF THIRTY-TWO PERSONS. Collision Between the Steamer and a Propeller off Cape Race. PROBABLE LOSS OF TWO TO THREE HUNDRED LIVES. FIVE BOAT LOADS OF PASSENGERS MISSING. INSTANT DESTRUCTION OF THE ARCTIC.

docs.lead_paragraph: The melancholy particulars of the loss of the Collins steamship ARCTIC were spread before our readers yesterday in an Extra Edition of the DAILY TIMES, and in a large part of our regular edition. The City was...

headline.main: MURDER TRIALS.; COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER. Trial of Charles Juger for the Murder of John Moran. CASE OF DR. GRAHAM.

docs.lead_paragraph: Before Hurt. Judge Mitchell. The Court was opened this morning about 11 o'clock. Long previous to that hour, however, the room was crowded by spectators, brought together probably by a desire to see the prisoner Graham, now awaiting his sentence for the murder of Col. Loring.

docs.lead_paragraph: There has been some discussion in the London newspapers touching a reported speech, said to have been spoken by Prince ALBERT at the last dinner he partook of at Boulogne with M. BONAPARTE, "Emperor of the French by the grace of God and the will of the French People."

headline.main: CITY POLITICS.; Resolutions--Meeting Adjourned in Confusion. Nomination of John N. Genin for Nayer.

docs.lead_paragraph: Agreeably to a call issued during the past week, a considerable number of citizens, independent of party, assembled at the Hall No. 600 Broadway, for the purpose or putting the name of JOHN N. GENIN, the hatter in nomination as an independent candidate for Mayor, at the approaching election.

headline.main: THE LORING TRAGEDY.; COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER. Trial of Robert M. Graham, M. D., for the Murder of Col. Charles Loring. Application of the Jury to be Discharged in Consequence of an Imputation Thrown on One Member, Mr. Geo, Wellman Wright, Withdrawn by Consent, and Proceeded with Before Eleven Jurors.

docs.lead_paragraph: Before Hon. Judge Mitchell. It being known that Mr. O'Conor would sum up the case this morning for the defence, there was an extraordinary press of persons before the doors of the Court at an early hour, anxious to hear the eloquent counsel. Several ladies (among whom was Mrs. O'Conor) were present, and were accommodated with chairs within the bar. Dr. Graham, his wife and friends, took their usual seats near counsel.

headline.main: Death from Malpractice--Absconding of an Abortionist--Affidavit of the Deceased's Husband.

docs.lead_paragraph: From the Rondout Courier. CASE OF MRS. S. REYNOLDS-UNFORTUNATE DEATH. Under our obituary head last week we announced the sudden death of Mrs. SAMUEL REYNOLDS, of Kingston. The circumstances attending her death seemed to demand an investigation, and the Assistant District Attorney, J. C. PERRY, and Coroner HAYES, were engaged with a jury some four or five days collecting testimony role.

headline.main: Sudden Death--A Husband Supposed to Have Been Killed by His Wife.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. James O. Frazer returned to his home, a few miles from this city, and in this (Fayette) County, on Saturday night last, 30th ult., after he had been in New-York, attending the sale of different lots of cattle, which were sent to him from time to time by his partner, Mr. Lewis Castleman, of this county.
